<a href="https://simplisafe.com/save?utm_source=morningbrew&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=20200725" style="border-bottom:none!important;" target="_blank" class=""><img alt="SimpliSafe" style="width:100%;max-width: 150px; display: inline; vertical-align: middle;" width="150" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL2NvbXBhbnkvbG9nby8xNy8xNTc2MDc3MTcyLWxvZ29fbm9sb2NrLnBuZyIsImJ1Y2tldCI6ImNvbWV0LW1vcm5pbmdicmV3IiwiZWRpdHMiOnsicmVzaXplIjp7IndpZHRoIjoxMDAwLCJoZWlnaHQiOm51bGx9fX0="></a>

<td style="padding-top:20px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Good morning, </strong>we hope your weekend is going well so far. If not, maybe this will make it better: Tomorrow, we'll be sending our Sunday newsletter, Light Roast, to every Morning Brew subscriber.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Light Roast is our premium newsletter typically reserved for subscribers with at least three referrals. But, it's the summer and sometimes you just gotta shake things up. And we have a fun edition for you tomorrow.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">We'll see you then, and remember...if you want Light Roast every Sunday all it takes is getting three other people signed up to the Brew. It's so easy a cavema—nevermind. </p>

<div class="c6 " style="margin-bottom:7px">
<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
BANKING
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/07/24/goldman-reaches-settlement-malaysia-1mdb-scandal?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Goldman Gets Hit With the Bill
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="Check for Goldman Sachs" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8xODQ3L2NoZWNrX3BsZWFzZS5qcGciLCJidWNrZXQiOiJvc2xvLXByb2R1Y3Rpb24iLCJlZGl0cyI6eyJyZXNpemUiOnsid2lkdGgiOjEwMDAsImhlaWdodCI6bnVsbH19fQ==">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Francis Scialabba</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Yesterday, Goldman Sachs <a href="https://www.cnn.com/2020/07/24/investing/goldman-sachs-1mdb-malaysia/index.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">agreed</a> to a $3.9 billion settlement with the Malaysian government to start to close the book on the massive 1MDB scandal that gripped the financial world. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>
</span><span><strong style="color:#000">Get your popcorn out</strong></span><span>: This is the closest thing to a summer blockbuster as we’re going to get.</span>
</li>
</ul>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">The backstory</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">In 2012–2013, Goldman Sachs raised $6.5 billion for Malaysian sovereign wealth fund 1Malaysia Development Bhd. (1MDB). However, over the ensuing decade, much of that money was allegedly <a href="https://www.ft.com/content/b2bd3773-7eb1-4440-8b2e-f1250f942a78?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">stolen, siphoned, or redirected</a> into everything from high-end art and real estate to superyachts and Vegas parties. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>
</span><span><strong style="color:#000">You like irony?</strong></span><span> Some of the money was used to fund a movie depicting another episode of financial funny business, </span><span><em>The Wolf of Wall Street. </em></span><span>
</span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Those familiar with the scandal know at the center of it all was Malaysian financier Jho Low, who far from being behind bars, maintains his innocence and is still at large. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>If you want the lowdown on Jho Low, Bradley Hope and Tom Wright’s </span><span><a href="https://www.amazon.com/Billion-Dollar-Whale-Fooled-Hollywood/dp/031643650X?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">book</a></span><span> </span><span><em>Billion Dollar Whale </em></span><span>is a fantastic read. </span>
</li>
</ul>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">What is Goldman paying for?</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The Wall Street investment bank is paying $2.5 billion to the Malaysian government and promised another $1.4 billion from the sale of seized assets related to the scandal. As part of the deal, the Malaysian government has agreed to <a href="https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-07-24/goldman-malaysia-reach-3-9-billion-settlement-deal-over-1mdb?sref=KkPzpZvz&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">drop criminal charges</a> against the bank. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>But Goldman isn't done—it also needs to settle up with U.S. authorities. “The DOJ settlement could wipe out most of the great 2Q they just put up,” Evercore ISI's Glenn Schorr wrote in a letter to clients.</span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Bottom line:</strong> Goldman Sachs says it plans to "materially increase its provisions for litigation and regulatory proceedings" for Q2. Translation: They got a big ol’ bill to pay.</p>

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
SEMICONDUCTOR
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/07/24/intel-falls-amd-soars-news-7nm-chip-tech-delay?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
We Have Good Intel—the Smaller Chip the Better
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Three nanometers. A distance so small you can barely fathom it, but one that may determine the future of the chip industry. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Yesterday, Intel's stock slid more than 16% after it said it would <a href="https://finance.yahoo.com/news/intel-considers-once-heresy-not-013625863.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">delay</a> the rollout of its 7-nanometer chip technology by a year. Intel is moving forward with its 10-nanometer process...but in this highly competitive industry, tens of billions in market value go to those who can make the next generation of smaller and more efficient transistors. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">That’s where AMD comes in. Shares of the Intel rival gained nearly 15% yesterday, pushed along by Intel’s sour announcement. It’s already making 7nm chips for laptops, and eclipsed <a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/intel-reports-profit-surge-but-warns-of-further-delays-on-advanced-chips-11595536707?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">more than 17% market share</a> in personal computer CPUs in Q1, per Mercury Research. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>We haven’t even mentioned Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. (TSMC), the grandaddy of semiconductors. It’s the No. 1 contract manufacturer of chips globally and will benefit from any Intel stumble.</span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Zoom out: </strong>At its developer conference last month, Apple said it would be <a href="https://www.cnbc.com/2020/07/24/intel-chip-delay-shows-exactly-why-apple-is-right-to-move-to-arm.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">ditching</a> Intel to make its own chips for the Mac. Wise move?</p>

METALS
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/07/24/gold-hits-alltime-high?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Literally Everyone Rn
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>

<!--[if mso]>

<!--[if !mso]>--><!-- -->
<img class="story-header-image" alt="Duck diving into a mountain of gold " style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" src="https://media.giphy.com/media/gQdejV5BBChHi/giphy.gif">

<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Giphy</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">All that glitters actually <em>is</em> gold these days—yesterday, the precious metal surged to an <a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/gold-climbs-to-all-time-high-topping-2011-record-11595612234?mod=hp_lead_pos4&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">all-time high</a> of $1,897.50 a troy ounce, buoyed by, well you'll see…</p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">Bullion is hot in the streets</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Gold has been considered a safe harbor for investors for its ability to hold long-term value and hedge against inflation. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>As geopolitical tensions turn up to volume 11 and central banks pump money into global financial systems, “You couldn’t create a better playbook for gold to perform,” Steven Dunn, head of a $2.2 billion gold ETF, told the WSJ.</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Meanwhile, the U.S. dollar has reversed its upward trend and decreased in value relative to other global currencies. That typically correlates to a rise in the price of precious metals. </span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">It's a gold rush: </strong>Investors <a href="https://finance.yahoo.com/news/gold-nears-1-900-veteran-012431232.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">poured $3.8 billion</a> into precious metals funds the week to July 22—the second-largest weekly amount ever, according to data analyzed by Bank of America.  </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Bottom line:</strong> If you have gold teeth fillings, your net worth is going up by the day. </p>

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
FOOD
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/07/24/vital-farms-files-go-public?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
For Eggs, Going Viral on Instagram Is Just the Start
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The country’s largest producer of pasture-raised eggs, Vital Farms, has <a href="https://www.nasdaq.com/articles/pasture-raised-egg-producer-vital-farms-sets-terms-for-%24125-million-ipo-2020-07-24?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">filed to go public</a> on the Nasdaq. And investors could be lining up like it’s the omelette bar at a Princeton eating club. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">That’s because this omelette bar is focused on ethically produced eggs and related products, which Vital Farms claims can command up to 3x the price of commodity eggs. Right now, the company says it only has 2% household penetration for its pasture-raised shell eggs. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">More Vital signs:</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Revenue was $155 million for the 12 months ended March 31, 2020. </span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>The number of stores carrying its brands has grown to more than 13,000 from around 4,200 five years ago, reports </span><span><a href="https://www.fooddive.com/news/pasture-raised-egg-producer-vital-farms-files-for-ipo/581385/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Food Dive</a></span><span>. It sells in supermarket giants like Kroger, Target, and Whole Foods. </span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>The company has raised at least </span><span><a href="https://www.thestreet.com/ipo/news/vital-farms-ipo?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">$43 million</a></span><span> from investors. </span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Zoom out: </strong>Whether it’s scrambled, fried, soft boiled, hard boiled, sunny side up, sunny side down (?), over easy, over medium, poached, deviled, angeled, basted, or roasted on a spit over a campfire, Americans are eating way more eggs. We even have a chart to back that up.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><img src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8xODUwL3Vfc19wZXJfY2FwaXRhX2VnZ19jb25zdW1wdGlvbl9jaGFydC5wbmciLCJidWNrZXQiOiJvc2xvLXByb2R1Y3Rpb24ifQ==" class="img-responsive" width="640" style="width:100% !important;max-width: 640px; width: 100%;" alt="" data-reactroot=""></p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;line-height: 22px;"><small> <em>United Egg Producers</em> </small></p>

SATURDAY HEADLINES
</h3>

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The media industry is loopier than ever these days, so we assembled four different headlines to test your BS sensors. Three of the headlines below are real, while one is made up. Can you spot the fake? </p>
<ol style="list-style-type: lower-alpha;">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>"Four-year-old </span><span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/books/2020/jul/22/four-year-old-lands-book-deal-poetry-nadim-shamma-sourgen-kate-clanchy?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">lands book deal</a></span><span> for his 'astonishing' poetry"</span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>"Gmail tops Twitter, Instagram as the </span><span><a href="https://media.giphy.com/media/aOften89vRbG/giphy.gif?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">most used iPhone application</a></span><span> in the first week of July"</span>
</li>

collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eYesterday, Goldman Sachs \u003ca href=\"https://www.cnn.com/2020/07/24/investing/goldman-sachs-1mdb-malaysia/index.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eagreed\u003c/a\u003e to a $3.9 billion settlement with the Malaysian government to start to close the book on the massive 1MDB scandal that gripped the financial world. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003e\n\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eGet your popcorn out\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e: This is the closest thing to a summer blockbuster as we’re going to get.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eThe backstory\u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eIn 2012–2013, Goldman Sachs raised $6.5 billion for Malaysian sovereign wealth fund 1Malaysia Development Bhd. (1MDB). However, over the ensuing decade, much of that money was allegedly \u003ca href=\"https://www.ft.com/content/b2bd3773-7eb1-4440-8b2e-f1250f942a78?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003estolen, siphoned, or redirected\u003c/a\u003e into everything from high-end art and real estate to superyachts and Vegas parties. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003e\n\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eYou like irony?\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e Some of the money was used to fund a movie depicting another episode of financial funny business, \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003cem\u003eThe Wolf of Wall Street. \u003c/em\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\n\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThose familiar with the scandal know at the center of it all was Malaysian financier Jho Low, who far from being behind bars, maintains his innocence and is still at large. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eIf you want the lowdown on Jho Low, Bradley Hope and Tom Wright’s \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.amazon.com/Billion-Dollar-Whale-Fooled-Hollywood/dp/031643650X?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ebook\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003cem\u003eBillion Dollar Whale \u003c/em\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003eis a fantastic read. \u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eWhat is Goldman paying for?\u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThe Wall Street investment bank is paying $2.5 billion to the Malaysian government and promised another $1.4 billion from the sale of seized assets related to the scandal. As part of the deal, the Malaysian government has agreed to \u003ca href=\"https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-07-24/goldman-malaysia-reach-3-9-billion-settlement-deal-over-1mdb?sref=KkPzpZvz\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003edrop criminal charges\u003c/a\u003e against the bank. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eBut Goldman isn't done—it also needs to settle up with U.S. authorities. “The DOJ settlement could wipe out most of the great 2Q they just put up,” Evercore ISI's Glenn Schorr wrote in a letter to clients.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBottom line:\u003c/strong\u003e Goldman Sachs says it plans to \"materially increase its provisions for litigation and regulatory proceedings\" for Q2. Translation: They got a big ol’ bill to pay.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: style=\"color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;\"\u003e\n\u003cfont color=\"#000000\"\u003e\nWe Have Good Intel—the Smaller Chip the Better\n\u003c/font\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003c/h1\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThree nanometers. A distance so small you can barely fathom it, but one that may determine the future of the chip industry. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eYesterday, Intel's stock slid more than 16% after it said it would \u003ca href=\"https://finance.yahoo.com/news/intel-considers-once-heresy-not-013625863.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003edelay\u003c/a\u003e the rollout of its 7-nanometer chip technology by a year. Intel is moving forward with its 10-nanometer process...but in this highly competitive industry, tens of billions in market value go to those who can make the next generation of smaller and more efficient transistors. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThat’s where AMD comes in. Shares of the Intel rival gained nearly 15% yesterday, pushed along by Intel’s sour announcement. It’s already making 7nm chips for laptops, and eclipsed \u003ca href=\"https://www.wsj.com/articles/intel-reports-profit-surge-but-warns-of-further-delays-on-advanced-chips-11595536707?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003emore than 17% market share\u003c/a\u003e in personal computer CPUs in Q1, per Mercury Research. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eWe haven’t even mentioned Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. (TSMC), the grandaddy of semiconductors. It’s the No. 1 contract manufacturer of chips globally and will benefit from any Intel stumble.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eZoom out: \u003c/strong\u003eAt its developer conference last month, Apple said it would be \u003ca href=\"https://www.cnbc.com/2020/07/24/intel-chip-delay-shows-exactly-why-apple-is-right-to-move-to-arm.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003editching\u003c/a\u003e Intel to make its own chips for the Mac.
